THE CREIGHTON UNIVERSITY
OMAHA 31, NEBRASKA
January 23, 1959
COMMUNICATION ARTS
RADIO. TELEVISION. FILM
OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR
Dr. Harry J. Skornia
Executive Director NAEB
lit Gregory Hall
Urbana, Illinois
Dear Harry:
Thanks for the draft of the McLuhan project. Both copies
were the same, but it’s characteristic of your thoroughness to be
sure I received the second draft.
You’ve obviously done an excellent job of translating McLuhan
into intelligible terms—no easy task.’
SISfo'uYS
AHf
JAN 26 1959
i
The only part I’m doubtful about is Section V, where refer¬
ence is made to the influence of the telegraph on the press. Frank
Byrne, one of our bright young men in the history department, did
a great deal of work in nineteenth-century newspapers for his
doctoral dissertation. He greatly questions Marshall’s generaliza¬
tions about the influence of the telegraph on press format and the
nature of reporting. Frank's pointed questions (I did not hear
them myself) apparently got under Marshall's skin because he asked
me afterward who the young man was. Perhaps you’ll want to make
at least a mental note to see that that part of the work is checked
over. Probably I could get Frank to do it for one. Another good £tJ*
man would be Ben Yablonsky of the NYU School of Journalism. Then
there is the whole stable of journalism personnel right there in
Gregory HallJ
It was good to see you again in Minneanolis. I’m sorry you
were in such a hurry at the airport that I didn't have time to
introduce you to my brother and his wonderful family.
Sincerely,
(j^ v C , L(J
P. C. Williams, S. J.
Director, Communication Arts
